titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tyler Gatewood Kent Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 08:49

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Tyler Kent, a code clerk at the American embassy in London, was tried in 1940 by the British government for violation of the Official Secrets Act. The papers, assembled by Charles Parsons, include correspondence, a transcript of the British trial, newspaper clippings, photographs, notes, legal papers related to Kent v. United States and printed matter.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The entire collection is available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 20 instead of the originals.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tyler Gatewood Kent Papers (MS 310). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Papers relating to Tyler Kent's conviction under the British Official Secrets Act are available on microfilm (500 frames on 1 reel, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Tyler Gatewood Kent Papers concern the case of Tyler G. Kent, a code clerk in the United States Embassy in London, who was tried and convicted in Great Britain in October, 1940, for violating the Official Secrets Act. Kent made and kept copies of secret communications between President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, then First Lord of the Admiralty. Kent was arrested by the British and charged with espionage, although he was finally jailed for the lesser charge of theft of goverment documents. Charles Parsons, a conservative polemicist and ideologist, became involved in the attempts of Mrs. Ann H.P. Kent (mother of Tyler Kent) to bring the case before the public. Most of the papers in this collection are related to their efforts to publicize the case and to Tyler G. Kent's later attempts to explain his actions.

The papers consist of correspondence, a transcript of the British trial, newspaper clippings, photographs of Parsons and Kent, notes, legal papers related to Kent v. United States , and printed matter spanning from 1940-1963. The correspondence is in chronological order but there is an index at the back of this register. The papers are also available as microfilm HM 20, and copyflo from the latter part of the film (corresponding to the January 1972 addition to the papers) is in folders 17 and 18.
The Tyler G. Kent papers were given to the Yale University Library by Charles Parsons. For further information, see the register of the Charles Parsons papers, Manuscript Group No. 387.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.
